subsection.text: Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, in this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State and Baltimore City.
“Includes” or “including” means includes or including by way of illustration and not by way of limitation.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: A state, possession, or territory of the United States;
The District of Columbia; or
The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

subsection.text: “Tax collector” means the person or governmental unit responsible for collecting a tax.
The fiscal year for each county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district in the State begins on July 1 of a calendar year and ends on June 30 of the next calendar year.
Each county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district shall use the fiscal year for:

paragraph.text: Appropriating money;
Authorizing expenditures; and
Balancing books and accounts.

section.text: A political subdivision of the State may adopt the accrual method for reporting revenues for purposes of preparing and revising its annual budget.

subsection.text: In this section, “legal holiday” means:

paragraph.text: The day on which a legal holiday, as defined in Article 1, § 27 of the Code, is observed; or
A federal legal holiday.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, when under State or local law, the last day to pay a tax, file a tax return, or perform any other act that relates to taxes under this article falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, performance of the act is considered timely if the act is performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday.
For purposes of this section, the last day to perform an act is the last day of any authorized extension of time.

A requirement in this article that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by a signed statement made under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the knowledge, information, and belief of the individual making the statement.
The oath or affirmation shall be made:

paragraph.text: Before an individual authorized to administer oaths, who shall certify in writing to have administered the oath or taken the affirmation; or
By a signed statement that:

subparagraph.text: Is in the document or attached to and made part of the document; and
Is expressly made under the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: If the procedures provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section are used, the affidavit subjects the individual making it to the penalties for perjury to the same extent as an oath or affirmation made before an individual authorized to administer oaths.
A document made under oath shall be signed:

paragraph.text: For a corporation, by an officer of the corporation authorized to do so;
For a sole proprietorship, by its owner; or
For a partnership, by a partner authorized to do so.

section.text: Before any license may be issued under this article to an employer to engage in an activity in which the employer may employ a covered employee, as defined in § 9-101 of the Labor and Employment Article, the employer shall file with the issuing authority:

paragraph.text: A certificate of compliance with the Maryland Workers’ Compensation Act; or
The number of a workers’ compensation insurance policy or binder.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administrator” means the chief administrative officer of a county or municipal corporation.

“Department head” means the head of a separate unit of a county or municipal corporation who reports directly to an elected executive or administrator or directly to the governing body of the county or municipal corporation.
“Employee” does not include an elected official, a department head, or an administrator.
“Regional agency” means an agency created under State law that provides governmental services to more than one political subdivision.

A county or municipal corporation may not require an employee to reside within the State, county, or municipal corporation or within a required distance of the State, county, or municipal corporation as a condition of employment.

Subject to subsection (c) of this section, a county or municipal corporation may not discriminate between residents and other citizens of the State or any other state in employment, promotion, demotion, layoff, and discharge decisions.

subsection.text: A county or municipal corporation may grant a resident of the State, county, or municipal corporation additional points or credits in employment or promotion decisions if the points or credits are provided under provisions of a merit system established by the county or municipal corporation by local law or ordinance.

A regional agency may not require an employee as a condition of employment to reside within the State or a political subdivision for which the regional agency provides governmental services or within a required distance of the State or a political subdivision for which the agency provides governmental services.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Chief executive officer” means:

subparagraph.text: The Mayor of Baltimore City; or
The County Executive of Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: “Political subdivision” means:

subparagraph.text: Baltimore City; or
Montgomery County.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a candidate for the office of the chief executive officer of a political subdivision shall be a resident of the political subdivision for at least 6 months preceding the general election for the chief executive officer.

If the charter of a political subdivision contains a durational residency requirement that is longer than 6 months, the longer durational residency requirement shall be retained if the governing body of the political subdivision reaffirms the longer durational residency requirement by enactment of an ordinance effective no later than 4 weeks prior to the filing deadline specified in § 5-303(a) of the Election Law Article.
In this section, “local government” means:

paragraph.text: A county;
A municipal corporation;
A special taxing district; or
A regional governmental entity created by State law that provides services in more than one county.

subsection.text: A local government may not print or have printed a local government employee’s Social Security number on any type of identification card.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Assessments and Taxation.
“Governing body” means the board of commissioners, county or municipal council, board of directors, or other governing body of a local entity.

“Local entity” means a county, municipal corporation, bicounty or multicounty agency, public authority, special taxing district, or other political subdivision or unit of a political subdivision of this State.

A local entity shall designate a citizen of this State who resides in the State, a Maryland corporation, or an officer of the local entity as its resident agent by filing for record with the Department:

subparagraph.text: A certification of the person whom the charter of the local entity authorizes to accept service of process for the local entity; or
If the charter does not designate a person for service, a certified copy of a resolution of the local entity’s governing body that authorizes the designation.

paragraph.text: If a local entity changes its resident agent, the local entity shall file for record with the Department:

subparagraph.text: A certification of the person whom the charter of the local entity authorizes to accept service of process for the local entity; or
If the charter does not designate a person for service, a certified copy of a resolution of the local entity’s governing body that authorizes the designation.

paragraph.text: A local entity may change the address for its resident agent by filing for record with the Department a statement of the change signed by the chairman or other principal officer of its governing body.
A resident agent whose address changes may notify the Department by filing for record with the Department a statement of the change signed by or for the resident agent.
A resident agent may resign by filing with the Department a statement of resignation.

subsection.text: There is no fee for a filing under this section.
A designation, change of agent, change of address, or resignation is effective as provided in the Corporations and Associations Article for a corporate resident agent.

paragraph.text: Service of process on a resident agent of a local entity constitutes effective service of process under the Maryland Rules on the local entity in an action, suit, or proceeding that is pending, filed, or instituted against the local entity.

Any notice required by law to be served by personal service on a resident agent or other agent or officer of a local entity may be served in the manner provided by the Maryland Rules relating to service of process on local entities.
Service under the Maryland Rules is equivalent to personal service on a resident agent or other agent or officer of a local entity.

section.text: The population count used after each decennial census for the purpose of creating the legislative districts that are used to elect the governing body of a county or a municipal corporation:

paragraph.text: May not include individuals who:

subparagraph.text: Were incarcerated in State or federal correctional facilities, as determined by the decennial census; and
Were not residents of the State before their incarceration; and

paragraph.text: Shall count individuals incarcerated in the State or federal correctional facilities, as determined by the decennial census, at their last known residence before incarceration if the individuals were residents of the State.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, a county or municipal corporation may:

subparagraph.text: Pay the wage of an employee by direct deposit as provided in subsection (b) of this section; and
Require an employee to receive the payment of wages by direct deposit as a condition of employment.

paragraph.text: A county or municipal corporation may not require the payment of wages by direct deposit for an employee:

subparagraph.text: Who was hired before October 1, 2011, unless the county or municipal corporation, before October 1, 2011, required by local law, regulation, or collective bargaining agreement, the payment of wages by direct deposit;
Whose employment is not conditioned on the employee receiving the payment of wages by direct deposit; or
Who:

sub-subparagraph.text: Does not have a personal bank account; and
Informs the employee’s employer that the employee wishes to opt out of direct deposit.

paragraph.text: If a county or municipal corporation elects to pay wages by direct deposit, an employee who is not required to receive the payment of wages by direct deposit may elect to receive the payment of wages by direct deposit in accordance with subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: If a county or municipal corporation elects to pay the wages of its employees by direct deposit, the county or municipal corporation shall:

paragraph.text: Provide an employee who is required or elects to receive the payment of wages by direct deposit with an electronic fund transfer authorization form;
Deposit the wage of an employee into a personal bank account selected by the employee on the electronic fund transfer authorization form; and
Each time the county or municipal corporation pays the wage of an employee by direct deposit, provide the employee with a direct deposit statement that includes:

subparagraph.text: The total amount of the wage;
Any amount deducted from the wage; and
The amount of the wage directly deposited into the personal bank account selected by the employee.

paragraph.text: An employee who is required or elects to receive the payment of wages by direct deposit shall complete and submit to the county or municipal corporation the electronic fund transfer authorization form provided to the employee under subsection (b) of this section.

An employee who is required or elects to receive the payment of wages by direct deposit shall select a personal bank account for the direct deposit of the employee’s wages that is at a financial institution that participates in the automated clearinghouse network.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, an employee may change the personal bank account or the financial institution designated on an electronic fund transfer authorization form by completing and submitting a new electronic fund transfer authorization form to the county or municipal corporation.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Department” means the Department of Legislative Services.
“Financial officer” means the treasurer or other financial officer of a political subdivision.
“Political subdivision” includes:

subparagraph.text: A county;
A municipal corporation in the State;
A special taxing district in the State; and
A public corporation of the State.

paragraph.text: If a political subdivision is authorized to incur debt to be redeemed from a fee, charge, or the proceeds of a levy, the financial officer of the political subdivision shall submit to the State Treasurer and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the Department a comprehensive report on the financial condition of the political subdivision as of the end of that fiscal year.

A political subdivision shall submit the report required under paragraph (1) of this subsection in accordance with the timeframes required under Article 19, § 37 of the Code for the submission to the Department of annual financial reports of counties, municipal corporations, and special taxing districts.

subsection.text: A report under this section shall be on the form that the Department provides.
A report under this section shall include the affidavit of the financial officer and all of the following information that applies to the political subdivision:

paragraph.text: The assessed valuation of taxable and tangible property in the political subdivision;
The total indebtedness of the political subdivision;
The following categories of the total indebtedness:

subparagraph.text: Bond indebtedness that is redeemable from the proceeds of general and ad valorem taxes;
Temporary or floating indebtedness;
Obligations that are incurred in anticipation of tax collection;
Current bills payable;
Contingent liability that results from the guaranty of an obligation of another political subdivision; and
Self–liquidating bond indebtedness;

paragraph.text: As to self–liquidating bond indebtedness:

subparagraph.text: The amount of indebtedness for each project; and
The source of the revenue for its liquidation;

paragraph.text: As to each sinking fund for retirement of obligations:

subparagraph.text: Each obligation for which the fund is established;
The amount of the fund; and
The manner in which money in the fund is invested;

paragraph.text: As to the tax levy for the fiscal year for which the report is made:

subparagraph.text: The amount of the levy imposed;
The amount of the levy collected; and
Separate items for:

sub-subparagraph.text: The amount of any special assessment levied; and
The amount of that assessment collected;

paragraph.text: As to the tax levy for each of the 3 fiscal years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which the report is made:

subparagraph.text: The amount of the levy imposed; and
The amount of uncollected taxes;

paragraph.text: As to the population of the political subdivision:

subparagraph.text: The population in the most recent federal census; and
Any official or unofficial population estimates for the fiscal year for which the report is made;

paragraph.text: A copy of the most recent actuarial report on the pension system of the political subdivision, unless it is a county or municipal corporation and a member of the State pension system;
As to all categories of indebtedness:

subparagraph.text: Variable interest rate debt instruments;
Interest rate exchange agreements or swaps; and
Other derivatives, including futures and options; and

paragraph.text: Any other information about the financial affairs of the political subdivision that the Department finds pertinent or appropriate and necessary to show accurately the financial condition of the political subdivision.

subsection.text: On request of the State Treasurer, a financial officer shall submit an updated report on the indebtedness of the political subdivision as required in subsection (d) of this section.

paragraph.text: A financial officer may not fail to:

subparagraph.text: Submit a report under this section; or
Resubmit a report that meets the requirements of this section within 15 days after receiving notice that the Department finds the report inadequate.

paragraph.text: If a financial officer violates any provision of this subsection, the political subdivision employing the financial officer is liable to the State for a penalty of $10 for each day or part of a day for which the report is overdue.

subsection.text: On or before April 30 following the end of a fiscal year, the Department of Legislative Services shall report on the status of the pension system of each county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district in the State.
The report shall be based on information that:

paragraph.text: The county, municipal corporation, or special taxing district submits under § 2-101 of this title; or
The State Retirement Agency provides.

subsection.text: The governing body of each county shall prepare and publish annually in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the respective county, a summary statement of the expenses of the county. The published summary shall state that an itemized statement of county expenses is available for public inspection in the office of the county governing body during the county’s business hours. A clerk of the county who fails to perform the duty imposed by this section shall forfeit $100.

If the charter of any county that has adopted home rule under Article XI-A of the Maryland Constitution requires the publication of financial information in a manner that differs from the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, the provisions of the charter shall control.
In this section, the word “regulation” has the meaning stated in § 10-101 of the State Government Article.
This section does not apply to a unit of the State government.
Each governmental unit and each quasi-governmental unit shall have those of its regulations that affect a member of the general public compiled, edited, published, and indexed.

section.text: It is the policy of this county that:

subsection.text: Public officials shall conduct the entire process of public business in an open and public manner so that the electors are advised of the performance of public officials and of the decisions that are reached in public activity and in making public policy;
Public agencies exist to aid in the conduct of the people’s business;
Public agencies shall deliberate matters, and take action on them, openly;
The people of this county do not yield their sovereignty to the agencies which serve them;
The people, in delegating authority, do not give their public servants the right to decide what is good for the people to know and what is not good for them to know; and
The people’s right to remain informed is protected so that they may retain control over the instruments they create.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Meeting” means the convening of a quorum of the constituent membership of a public agency to deliberate or act upon a matter over which the public agency has supervision, control, jurisdiction or advisory power.
“Official action” means the phases of the process in which a decision or recommendation is reached including receipt of information, deliberation and decision of a public agency.
“Public agency” includes:

paragraph.text: Any agency, assembly, authority, board, bureau, commission, committee, council, or department of St. Mary’s County, except as provided in § 4-209 of this subtitle, including advisory and quasi-judicial agencies, supported in whole or in part by public funds or authorized to expend public funds;
The St. Mary’s County Board of Education; and
Subcommittees and other subordinate units of the agencies above.

subsection.text: “Public business” means all matters within the jurisdiction of a public agency which are before an agency for official action or which reasonably, foreseeably may come before that agency in the future.
“Quorum” unless otherwise defined by applicable law, means a simple majority of the constituent membership of a public body.
“Staff meeting” means a meeting of three or more staff members or a combination of three or more staff members of a public agency.
All meetings of a public agency at which official action is taken regarding public business are open to the public, except as provided in § 4–210 of this subtitle.
Staff meetings of a public agency are open to the public.

All public agencies shall give written public notice of their regular meetings at the beginning of each calendar or fiscal year, or at the time the agency begins to function. This notice shall include the dates, times and places of the meetings.

All public agencies shall give supplemental written public notice of any special or rescheduled meeting, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, no later than 48 hours before the meeting. The notice shall include the agenda, date, time and place of the meeting.
Written public notice shall include, as a minimum:

paragraph.text: Posting a copy of the notice prominently at the principal office of the body holding the meeting or at the building in which the meeting is to be held;
Mailing a copy of the notice to any person who requests to be notified of the meetings.

subsection.text: When meetings are necessary to discuss unforeseen emergency conditions, an emergency meeting of a public agency may be scheduled. Reasonable effort shall be made to give notice of the date, time and place of an emergency meeting by telephone to the news media immediately after participants have been notified of the meeting.
This section does not apply to staff meetings.

section.text: A meeting of a public agency may be adjourned and reconvened at some other time without additional public notice provided:

subsection.text: Notice of the time and place of the reconvened meeting is given before adjournment;
The agenda for the reconvened meeting shall be published in advance; and
That the agenda is available to observers of the original meeting at its commencement.

section.text: Meetings required by this subtitle to be open to the public shall be conducted in areas having reasonable facilities for observation by the public.

subsection.text: The minutes of all public meetings of public agencies shall be taken and timely recorded, and shall be a public record open for inspection and copying by any person.
Minutes are not required of working sessions where final decisions are not made.
Recording of minutes are not required of staff meetings.

section.text: Public agencies conducting meetings required by this subtitle to be open to the public shall allow the use of recording and either recorded or live radio and television broadcast of the meetings. The public agencies may establish reasonable rules and regulations regarding the recording and broadcasting of the meetings.
This subtitle does not apply to the following public agencies:

subsection.text: The Judicial Branch;
Grand juries;
Petit juries;
Law-enforcement agencies.
Meetings of public agencies and meetings of the staff of public agencies may be conducted in executive session in the following situations only:

paragraph.text: When a public agency or members of the staff consider or discuss the assignment, promotion, resignation, salary, demotion, dismissal, reprimand, or appointment of a member of a public agency or employee, the session may be closed, unless the person requests in writing for an open session. The request is a matter of public record;
When a school board or its staff considers the disciplining of individual students unless the parent, guardian or student requests an open session of the board of education;
When a school board or its staff discusses specific students, families, or personnel, and the disclosure of the discussions could prove detrimental or harmful to those individuals;
When federal regulations prohibit an open meeting;
When State law specifically prohibits an open meeting;
When an open meeting would conflict with a condition for anonymity of the donor contained in a gift or bequest to a public agency;
When secrecy is necessary to prevent the premature disclosure of the format or content of examinations or the disclosure of results of examinations as they relate to individual students;
When a public agency discusses strategy in collective bargaining or litigation, or engages in collective bargaining;
When public agencies discuss the distribution of police forces to cope with public safety emergencies;
When public agencies discuss cost estimates for capital projects to be subsequently placed through the bidding process; and
When public agencies have a preliminary discussion concerning the purchase or disposition of real property.

subsection.text: An executive session may not be held without the prior announcement in an open meeting of the nature of the business of the executive session and only business specifically authorized by this section shall be taken up at the executive session.

The justification for holding an executive or closed meeting shall be indicated by a citation in the minutes. Such citation shall include the time of the commencement of the meeting, names of those in attendance, the reason for the session, and the time of the conclusion of the meeting, but need not be limited to that, at the discretion of the body holding the meeting.
An ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or decision may not be finally adopted at an executive session.

Any decision by a public agency to purchase or dispose of real property must be made in public session. Notice of intent to purchase or dispose of real property must be given at least 15 days before a voting session on the action.

section.text: Knowing violation of this subtitle on more than two occasions constitutes a misdemeanor.

paragraph.text: The circuit courts of this State have jurisdiction over any civil action brought to enforce the provisions of this subtitle.

Any person denied the rights conferred by this subtitle may commence a civil action by petitioning for mandamus, injunction or other appropriate remedy in any court of competent jurisdiction. The court shall hear the petition within seven days from the time it is made.
It is not necessary for the plaintiff to allege or prove an irreparable injury or injury different from the public at large. Violation of this subtitle is an injury to the public at large.

The court shall render a decree granting or denying all or part of the relief prayed for, determining the rights of the parties as to attorney’s fees and costs, and determining the effect of any action alleged to be in violation of this subtitle.
The provisions of this subtitle apply to conduct and actions occurring after July 1, 1976; and a party shall commence an action within one year of the alleged violation.

subsection.text: Any person who wilfully violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000 or imprisonment not to exceed one year, or both. Where a civil decree finding the defendant in violation of the provisions of this subtitle is not entered on at least one occasion prior to the occurrence of the alleged misdemeanor, a violation of this subtitle is presumed not to be wilful.

section.text: Action taken at a meeting not in conformity with this subtitle may be declared null and void, at the discretion of the court.

If the provisions of this subtitle conflict with any other statute, ordinance, regulation or rule, the provisions of this subtitle shall control, unless the provisions of existing law are more stringent.
This subtitle does not prevent a public agency from adopting reasonable rules and regulations for the maintenance of order at meetings.
This subtitle may be cited as the “St. Mary’s County Open Meetings Act”.

subsection.text: In this section, “electric company” has the meaning stated in § 1–101 of the Public Utilities Article.

On written request by a local government, an electric company shall sell to the local government some or all of the electric company’s existing street lighting equipment that is located within the local jurisdiction.
If the local government purchases street lighting equipment from an electric company, the local government shall pay to the electric company the fair market value of the street lighting equipment.

A local government that purchases the street lighting equipment in accordance with subsection (b) of this section shall be responsible for the maintenance of the street lighting equipment and may contract with an outside entity for the maintenance of the street lighting equipment.

paragraph.text: Any person who controls the right to use space on any pole, lamppost, or other mounting surface previously used in the local jurisdiction by the electric company for street lighting equipment shall allow a local government that has purchased the street lighting equipment to assume the rights and obligations of the electric company with respect to the space for the unexpired term of any lease or other agreement under which the electric company used the space.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, the local government may not restrict or prohibit universal access for electricity or any other service by assuming the rights and obligations of an electric company as to space on any pole, lamppost, or other mounting surface used for street lighting equipment.
Any dispute between an electric company and a local government arising under this subsection shall be submitted to the Public Service Commission for resolution.

subsection.text: Any county or municipality of the State of Maryland, in addition to the powers which it may now have, shall have the power and is hereby authorized to:

paragraph.text: Aid, assist, participate and cooperate with the United States or any agency thereof in constructing, erecting, financing, maintaining, using or operating any federal work, improvement or project, including dredging or flood control projects or other federal river and harbor and navigation works and improvements, and to agree to terms of local cooperation required by Congress and/or the federal agency in connection therewith;

Enter into, execute and perform any and all contracts and agreements with the United States or any agency thereof, in the form required thereby, obligating said county or municipality, in whole or in part, to construct, erect, finance, maintain, use, or operate any such federal works, improvements or projects or obligating said county or municipality to arrange, contract for, or supervise the construction, erection, financing, maintenance, use, or operation thereof;

Levy for, appropriate, and obligate necessary moneys to pay for the county’s or municipality’s share of the cost of such works, improvements, and projects and to obtain private loans and financing therefor;

Receive and accept and expend and use any funds donated or loaned by the federal government to assist in the construction, erection, financing, maintenance, use, or operation of any such works, improvements, and projects;

Subject to the provisions of Title 12 of the Real Property Article, purchase or condemn lands, rights-of-way, easements, and any other interests in land necessary for such improvements, works, and projects and to convey, lease, or otherwise transfer all or any part of such interests to the United States or any agency thereof; and
Enter on any lands, waters and premises for the purpose of making surveys, soundings, and examination in or for the furtherance of any such works, improvements, and projects.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this section the term “municipality” means any municipal or public corporation, special district and/or political subdivision of the State of Maryland.

Any act or contract authorized under the terms of this section, as re-enacted, and entered into or performed by any county or municipality prior to the effective date of the re-enactment hereof is approved, ratified, and validated as fully as if the said act or contract had been entered into or performed after the effective date of re-enactment.

section.text: Any county or Baltimore City, or any municipality of the State of Maryland, in addition to the powers which it may now have, is hereby authorized to enter into any agreements or contracts with the United States or any agency thereof, public drainage association, public watershed associations and other groups or agencies, including without limitation agreements, contracts, and obligations of repayment pursuant to the area redevelopment program (42 U.S.C. §§ 3161 and 3162), in constructing, erecting, financing, maintaining, using or operating any works of improvement.

subsection.text: Any county or municipality of the State may participate in federal programs of lower-income housing assistance and for this purpose, may: (1) enter into and perform contracts or agreements with the United States or federal agencies; (2) accept and expend assistance payments made with respect to existing, newly constructed, or substantially rehabilitated housing; (3) act as a public housing agency within the meaning of federal law; and (4) do all things necessary or convenient to its participation.

The powers conferred by this section are in addition to all other powers of counties and municipalities and may be exercised directly by the county or municipality or as otherwise provided by its governing body, whether or not the county or municipality has established a housing authority under the Housing Authorities Law. This section does not affect any powers conferred on housing authorities or on counties or municipalities by Housing Authorities Law or the housing cooperation law.

After consultation with the Department of Budget and Management, the Director of Planning shall adopt regulations that require a local government to submit information, as required in this section, on federal aid, including grants, instructional contracts, loans, research contracts, or other assistance.

paragraph.text: Each 6 months, a local government shall submit a summary notice to the Department of Planning if, during the 6-month period that the notice covers, the local government has received an award of federal aid in the form of an instructional contract, instructional grant, research contract, or research grant.
The summary notice shall state the amount of the award.
This subsection does not apply to an instructional contract, instructional grant, research contract, or research grant.
Within 30 days after a local government receives an award of federal aid, the local government shall submit to the Department of Planning a summary notice that states:

subparagraph.text: The amount of the award; and
If the award is conditioned on matching funds:

sub-subparagraph.text: The amount of those funds;
The source of those funds; and
The period for which those funds are required.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the pledge of any bonds or obligations issued upon the full faith and credit of Harford County or any general obligation bonds of the State of Maryland shall be accepted as sufficient collateral for the deposit of any funds of Harford County.
Each of the following entities is subject to the budget and fiscal policies and purchasing laws of the county in which it is located:

paragraph.text: Any county board of supervisors of elections;
Any State’s Attorney’s office;
Any sheriff’s office;
Any county board of liquor license commissioners; or
Any circuit court, but not the office of a clerk of court.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Maryland firm” means a business entity that has its principal office in the State.
“Nonresident firm” means a business entity that has its principal office out of the State.

When awarding a contract by competitive bidding, if the state in which a nonresident firm is located gives an advantage to its resident businesses, a political subdivision or any instrumentality of government within the State may give an identical advantage to the lowest responsive and responsible bid from a Maryland firm over that of the nonresident firm.
An advantage may include:

subparagraph.text: A percentage preference;
An employee residency requirement; or
Any other provision that favors a nonresident firm over a Maryland firm.

subsection.text: A county or municipal corporation that avails itself of the provisions of this subtitle may impose a tax not exceeding 3.2 cents on each $100 of assessable real property subject to the property tax in that county or municipal corporation or 8 cents on each $100 of assessable personal property and operating real property described in § 8-109(c) of the Tax - Property Article, to be collected according to law.

A tax imposed under subsection (a) of this section may be used only for the general protection and preservation of the public safety, peace, health and welfare of the State and the county or municipal corporation by providing the destitute and unemployed residents of the county or municipal corporation with:

paragraph.text: Assistance, food, shelter, supplies, necessities, and other relief, either alone or in conjunction and cooperation with the State or federal government; or
Work and labor, either alone or as a part of a general State or federal government plan.

subsection.text: Except for Baltimore City, a county or municipal corporation may borrow money and incur debt on its separate and individual faith and credit.

All money borrowed or obtained by a county or municipal corporation under subsection (a) of this section shall be used by that county or municipal corporation only for the general protection and preservation of the public safety, peace, health and welfare of the State and that county or municipal corporation by providing the destitute and unemployed residents of that county or municipal corporation with:

paragraph.text: Assistance, food, shelter, supplies, necessities, and other relief, either alone or in conjunction and cooperation with the State or federal government; or
Work and labor, either alone or as a part of a general State or federal government plan.

section.text: To avail itself of the provisions of this subtitle, the governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall enact a motion, resolution, or ordinance stating in substance that the county or municipal corporation has determined to avail itself of the provisions of this subtitle and binds itself to fulfill all obligations incurred under this subtitle.

Except for Baltimore City, a county or municipal corporation may issue its individual notes, certificates of indebtedness or other evidence of indebtedness for any amount borrowed or indebtedness incurred under this subtitle.
Subject to the limitations in this subtitle, the governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall determine, with respect to borrowing or indebtedness under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: The manner, method, means, and conditions by which the indebtedness shall be incurred or money borrowed;
The kind and character of obligations which shall be issued;
The form and substance of any and all obligations issued;
The rate of interest which any and all obligations shall bear;
The manner, method, or means of sale, both private or public, of any obligations issued;
The time or times when any indebtedness shall be incurred or money borrowed; and
The time or times when any obligation or obligations shall be issued.

section.text: The governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall have any and all necessary implied incidental powers to carry out the express powers stated in §§ 9-101 through 9-105 of this subtitle.
All obligations incurred under this subtitle shall mature, and must be paid, within 2 years after the date when the obligations were incurred.

No county or municipal corporation shall incur an indebtedness for the purposes set forth in § 9-101 of this subtitle, and under this subtitle, in excess of an aggregate amount equal to the total estimated amount that would be raised by a levy of 8 cents on the property tax rate for that county or municipal corporation.

Each county or municipal corporation that avails itself of the provisions of this subtitle by borrowing money or incurring indebtedness on its individual faith and credit shall levy a tax not exceeding 3.2 cents on each $100 of assessable real property subject to the property tax of that county or municipal corporation or 8 cents on each $100 of assessable personal property and operating real property described in § 8-109(c) of the Tax - Property Article, to be collected according to law, in an amount that will repay in full with interest the money or indebtedness incurred under this subtitle by the county or municipal corporation, within the period of 2 years after the indebtedness was incurred.

subsection.text: The administration, expenditure, and accounting of all sum or sums raised, borrowed, or obtained by any county under this subtitle shall be subject to the control of the county commissioners or the public body in the county that the county commissioners designate, including the county welfare board, the county civil works board, or any similar public body in the county cooperating with the State or federal government in the administration of public relief or civil works funds.

The administration, expenditure, and accounting of all sum or sums raised, borrowed, or obtained by any municipal corporation under this subtitle shall be subject to the control of the governing body of the municipal corporation or the public body that the governing body designates.

section.text: In Allegany County, all special taxing-area commissions or boards having the right to collect taxes or fees shall file an annual report with the County Commissioners accounting for all taxes collected and disbursed. This report shall be notarized and the Commissioners at their discretion may require a certified audit. This report shall be filed within 60 days after the end of the fiscal or calendar year. All reports shall be open to the public review at the courthouse and at a convenient location in the area where taxes or fees are collected.

This subtitle, being enacted to meet an emergency through the police power of the State, is hereby declared to be immediately necessary for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety and shall be liberally construed.

If any section or part of a section of this subtitle is held to be invalid for any reason, such holding shall not be construed as affecting the validity of any remaining section or part of a section of this subtitle, it being the legislative intent that the remainder of this subtitle shall stand, notwithstanding the invalidity of such section or part of a section.
A political subdivision of this State that, at any time, has the power to impose and collect a sales tax:

paragraph.text: May not thereby be construed to have the power to impose and may not impose a sales tax on advertising transactions or on advertisers at a rate or rates in excess of the rate or rates in a sales tax imposed generally on other business transactions or other businesses by the subdivision; and
May not impose a sales tax on advertising transactions or on advertisers except as part of the imposition of a sales tax generally on business transactions and businesses in the subdivision.

section.text: A political subdivision of this State that, at any time, has the power to impose and collect a gross receipts tax may not thereby be construed to have the power to impose and may not impose a gross receipts tax on the gross receipts of any person that are received from a sale of:

paragraph.text: Space used for advertising:

subparagraph.text: In any newspapers, magazines, periodicals, programs, directories, and other printed matter published in this State; or
On any billboard, structure, vehicle, or airborne device located in this State; or

paragraph.text: Time used for advertising on or in connection with any radio or television broadcast originating in this State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authorized county” means:

paragraph.text: A code county;
Calvert County;
Carroll County;
Cecil County;
Charles County;
Dorchester County;
Frederick County;
Garrett County;
St. Mary’s County;
Somerset County;
Talbot County;
Washington County; and
Wicomico County.

subsection.text: “Code county”:

paragraph.text: Means a county that has adopted home rule under Article XI-F of the Maryland Constitution; and
Includes:

subparagraph.text: Allegany County;
Caroline County;
Kent County;
Queen Anne’s County; and
Worcester County.

paragraph.text: “Hotel” means an establishment that offers sleeping accommodations for compensation.
“Hotel” includes:

subparagraph.text: An apartment;
A cottage;
A hostelry;
An inn;
A motel;
A rooming house; or
A tourist home.

subsection.text: “Hotel rental tax” means the tax authorized under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, “transient charge” means a hotel charge for sleeping accommodations for a period not exceeding 4 consecutive months.
In Frederick County, Garrett County, and Washington County, “transient charge” means a hotel charge for sleeping accommodations for a period not exceeding 30 days.
In Carroll County, “transient charge” means a hotel charge for sleeping accommodations for a period not exceeding 25 days.
“Transient charge” does not include any hotel charge for services or for accommodations other than sleeping accommodations.

section.text: This subtitle allows a hotel rental tax for an authorized county.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, an authorized county may impose, by resolution, a tax on a transient charge paid to a hotel located in that county.
Before Calvert County, Charles County, or St. Mary’s County imposes a hotel rental tax, the governing body of the county shall hold a public hearing, which:

paragraph.text: Shall be advertised twice by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county at least 10 days before the hearing; and
May not be part of the annual budget hearing.
In this subsection, “population center” means any portion of Cecil County, as specified by the Board of County Commissioners, that:

subparagraph.text: Is not larger than 10 square miles in geographic area; and
Has a population of at least 6,000 residents.

paragraph.text: Cecil County may impose the hotel rental tax only on a transient charge paid to a hotel located in a population center in the county.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitations in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, the hotel rental tax rate is the rate that the authorized county sets by resolution.
An authorized county may not set a hotel rental tax rate that exceeds:

paragraph.text: 3% in a code county;
5% in Calvert County;
5% in Carroll County;
3% in Cecil County;
5% in Charles County;
5% in Dorchester County;
5% in Frederick County;
6% in Garrett County;
5% in St. Mary’s County;
5% in Somerset County;
4% in Talbot County; and
6% in Wicomico County.

Notwithstanding subsection (b)(1) of this section, a code county, other than a code county in the Western Maryland class, may set a hotel rental tax rate that is greater than 3%, but not exceeding 5%, with the unanimous consent of the county commissioners for the county.

Notwithstanding subsection (b)(1) of this section, a code county in the Western Maryland class may set a hotel rental tax rate that is greater than 3%, but not exceeding 8%, with the unanimous consent of the county commissioners for the county.

subsection.text: The hotel rental tax rate in Washington County is 6%.
Calvert County and St. Mary’s County may provide, by resolution, a tax exemption for classes of hotels.

In Frederick County, the hotel rental tax does not apply to a hotel with 10 or fewer sleeping rooms in its main building and no more than 20 additional sleeping rooms in auxiliary structures on the hotel’s property.
In Washington County, the hotel rental tax does not apply to a transient charge paid to a hotel by:

paragraph.text: The federal government;
A state; or
An agency or instrumentality of a state or of the federal government.

subsection.text: In Carroll County, the hotel rental tax does not apply to a hotel with 10 or fewer sleeping rooms.

section.text: A person shall pay the hotel rental tax to the hotel when the person pays the transient charge.

subsection.text: A hotel shall:

paragraph.text: Give the person who is required to pay a transient charge a bill that identifies the transient charge as a separate item from any other charge; and
Collect the hotel rental tax from the person who pays the transient charge.

subsection.text: A hotel holds hotel rental tax collected in trust for the authorized county that imposes the tax until the hotel pays the tax to that county as required under this subtitle.
A hotel shall complete, sign, and file a hotel rental tax return with:

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a code county, on or before the 10th day of each month;

subparagraph.text: A code county in the Eastern Shore class established under Article 25B, § 2 of the Code, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Calvert County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Carroll County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Cecil County, on or before the 10th day of each month;
Charles County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Dorchester County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Frederick County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Garrett County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
St. Mary’s County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Somerset County, on or before the 21st day of each month;
Talbot County, on or before the 20th day of each month;
Washington County, on or before the 25th day of each month; and
Wicomico County, on or before the 20th day of each month.

subsection.text: A hotel rental tax return for an authorized county:

paragraph.text: Shall be made on the form that the county requires;
Shall contain the information that the county requires, including the amount of:

subparagraph.text: Transient charges paid to the hotel during the prior calendar month; and
The hotel rental tax required to be collected during the prior calendar month.

subsection.text: A hotel shall pay to the authorized county that imposes the hotel rental tax the tax collected for a calendar month with the return that covers that month.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a hotel is allowed, for administrative costs, a discount equal to 1.5% of the gross amount of hotel rental tax collected, if, on or before the due date, the hotel:

subparagraph.text: Files the hotel rental tax return; and
Pays the hotel rental tax.

paragraph.text: The Commissioners of Calvert County, Carroll County, Charles County, St. Mary’s County, and Washington County may determine whether a hotel is eligible to receive a discount.

section.text: An authorized county shall administer the hotel rental tax for that county.
To provide for orderly, systematic, and thorough administration of the hotel rental tax, an authorized county may adopt regulations that:

paragraph.text: Are consistent with this subtitle; and
Conform to the applicable provisions and regulations for the sales and use tax under Title 11 of the Tax - General Article.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall provide an authorized county with information to help the county to verify hotel rental tax liability.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller may charge an authorized county a reasonable fee for the cost of providing information.
The county shall treat the fee as a hotel rental tax administrative cost.

subsection.text: To cover the revenue that a treasurer collects under this subtitle, an authorized county may increase the surety bond that the county requires for its treasurer.
The county shall treat any additional premium due to a surety bond increase allowed under subsection (a) of this section as a hotel rental tax administrative cost.
Except for Talbot County, Washington County, Dorchester County, Frederick County, and Carroll County, an authorized county shall distribute the hotel rental tax revenue as follows:

paragraph.text: From the total revenue, a reasonable sum for hotel rental tax administrative costs to the general fund of the county;

In a code county and Calvert, Cecil, Garrett, and St. Mary’s counties, after the distribution in item (1) of this subsection, the revenue attributable to a hotel located in a municipal corporation to the municipal corporation; and
The remaining balance to the general fund of the county.
Cecil County may not deduct more than 5% of the revenue for administrative costs under subsection (a)(1) of this section.
Garrett County shall designate a part of the balance under subsection (a)(3) of this section for the promotion of the county.

subparagraph.text: Wicomico County may not deduct more than 5% of the revenue for administrative costs under subsection (a)(1) of this section.
If Wicomico County authorizes a hotel rental tax rate of 6%, the county shall distribute:

sub-subparagraph.text: 16.7% of the revenue to the Salisbury Zoological Park; and
16.7% of the revenue to the Wicomico County Youth and Civic Center to be used for its improvement and renovation.

subparagraph.text: Wicomico County shall deposit all remaining revenues, after the distributions under subsection (a)(1) of this section and subparagraphs (ii) and (iii) of this paragraph in the general funds of Wicomico County to underwrite the Wicomico County Convention and Visitors Bureau.
For purposes of this paragraph, actual administrative costs mean costs incurred for wages, postage, and supplies.
Washington County:

sub-subparagraph.text: Shall distribute 50% of the total hotel rental tax revenue collected in the county to the general fund of Washington County to be used to fund the Hagerstown/Washington County Convention and Visitors Bureau; and

Shall distribute the remaining balance after the distribution under item 1 of this subparagraph to a special fund, to be used only to cover actual administrative costs and legal fees incurred in administering the hotel rental tax, develop tourism attractions, enhance economic development, and support cultural and recreational projects in Washington County.

subparagraph.text: A municipal corporation in Washington County may apply to the Board of County Commissioners of Washington County for funding from the special fund established under subparagraph (ii)2 of this paragraph for an eligible project within the municipal corporation.
Each year before adoption of its annual budget, the Hagerstown/Washington County Convention and Visitors Bureau shall hold a public hearing on the proposed annual budget.
On or before September 1 of each year beginning in 2001:

sub-subparagraph.text: The Board of County Commissioners of Washington County shall report to the Washington County Senate and House Delegations of the General Assembly on the hotel rental tax revenue collected and the use of the hotel rental tax revenue for the preceding fiscal year; and

The Hagerstown/Washington County Convention and Visitors Bureau shall report to the Washington County Senate and House Delegations of the General Assembly on its use of the hotel rental tax revenue for the preceding fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: Frederick County shall distribute the hotel rental tax revenue as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: From the total revenue, a reasonable sum for hotel rental tax administrative costs to the general fund of the county; and
The remaining balance to the Tourism Council of Frederick County, Inc., with a portion of the balance designated by the County Commissioners to be used for a visitor center.

subparagraph.text: The internal auditor of the county shall conduct an audit of the financial records of the Tourism Council and report the findings to the County Commissioners.

paragraph.text: Dorchester County shall distribute:

subparagraph.text: 80% of the revenues attributable to a hotel located in a municipal corporation to that municipal corporation; and
The remaining revenues to the general fund of the county.

paragraph.text: Carroll County shall distribute the hotel rental tax revenue as follows:

subparagraph.text: A reasonable sum for hotel rental tax administrative costs to the general fund of the county; and
The remaining balance to the tourism and general promotion of Carroll County.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a)(2) of this section, if a code county in the Western Maryland class imposes a tax rate greater than 5%, the revenue attributable to the rate greater than 5% and attributable to a hotel located in a municipal corporation shall be distributed to the general fund of the county instead of to the municipal corporation.

subsection.text: An authorized county shall make the distributions required under this section between the 15th day and the 30th day of each calendar month.

paragraph.text: No later than October 1st of each year, a code county in the Western Maryland class shall prepare a report on the hotel rental tax for public distribution.
The report shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county and posted on the county’s Internet website.
The report shall include:

subparagraph.text: The amount of revenue the county collected from the hotel rental tax in the previous fiscal year;
An itemized statement of the use of hotel rental tax revenue; and
The name and salary of each position within the county agency that administers the hotel rental tax.

subsection.text: A code county in the Western Maryland class shall provide a copy of any audits performed annually relating to the hotel rental tax to the county Senate and House Delegations of the General Assembly.

If a hotel fails to pay the hotel rental tax as required by this subtitle, the hotel shall pay interest on the unpaid tax from the date on which the hotel is required to pay the tax to the date that the tax is paid.
The interest rate for each month or fraction of a month is:

paragraph.text: For Cecil County, Talbot County, Washington County, Wicomico County, and Dorchester County, 1%; and
For any other authorized county, 0.5%.

subsection.text: If a hotel fails to pay the hotel rental tax to an authorized county, except Talbot County or Wicomico County, within 1 month after the payment is due under § 9-311 of this subtitle, the hotel shall pay a tax penalty of 10% of the unpaid tax.

If a hotel fails to pay the hotel rental tax to Talbot County or Wicomico County within 120 days after the payment is due under § 9-311 of this subtitle, the hotel shall pay a tax penalty of 10% of the unpaid tax.

section.text: An authorized county may file a civil action to collect unpaid hotel rental tax.
An authorized county may collect unpaid hotel rental tax by distraint.

Unpaid hotel rental tax in a code county, Carroll County, Cecil County, Charles County, Dorchester County, Frederick County, Garrett County, Somerset County, Talbot County, Washington County, and Wicomico County is a lien against the real and personal property of the person owing the tax and is collectible in the same manner as the property tax may be collected under the Tax - Property Article.

paragraph.text: To protect hotel rental tax revenue, an authorized county may require a hotel to file security with that county in an amount that the county determines.
Cecil, Talbot, and Wicomico counties may require security under this section only if a hotel has been in default.

subsection.text: Security under this section shall be:

paragraph.text: A bond issued by a surety company that is:

subparagraph.text: Authorized to do business in the State; and
Approved by the Insurance Commissioner as to solvency and responsibility;

paragraph.text: Cash; or
Securities approved by the county.

subsection.text: If security is required under this section, the county shall give the hotel notice of the amount of security.
Within 5 days after a hotel receives notice that security is required, the hotel shall:

paragraph.text: File the security; or
Submit a written request for a hearing on the security requirement.
If a hearing is requested, the county shall hold a hearing to determine the necessity, propriety, and amount of the security.
The determination at the hearing is final, and the hotel shall comply within 15 days after the hotel receives notice of the determination.

subsection.text: Without notice to the hotel that files security under subsection (b)(2) or (3) of this section, the county at any time may:

paragraph.text: Apply the cash to the hotel rental tax due; or
Sell the security and apply the proceeds of the sale to the hotel rental tax due.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Camping shelter” means a tent or other collapsible structure that provides temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, or travel use.
“Recreational vehicle” means a vehicle, including a trailer, that provides temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, or travel use.
A county or municipal corporation may impose, by resolution or ordinance, a tax on the amount paid for:

subparagraph.text: The rental, leasing, or use of any space, facilities, or accommodations in a trailer park or mobile home court or park; or
The providing of any services by a trailer park or mobile home court or park.
The tax authorized under this subsection does not apply to any recreational vehicle or camping shelter intended and used for temporary occupancy only for a period of 30 days or less.

If a county or municipal corporation imposes the tax authorized under subsection (a-2) of this section, a tax imposed by the county or municipal corporation under this subsection does not apply to any recreational vehicle or camping shelter.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a county or municipal corporation may impose, by resolution or ordinance, a tax on the amount paid for:

subparagraph.text: The rental, leasing, or use of any space, facilities, or accommodations for a recreational vehicle or camping shelter in a trailer park or mobile home court or park, regardless of the period of occupancy; or

The providing of any services by a trailer park or mobile home court or park in connection with the rental, leasing, or use of any space, facilities, or accommodations for a recreational vehicle or camping shelter.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the rate of the tax authorized under this subsection may not exceed 3% of the amounts subject to the tax.
In Washington County the tax authorized under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: Is at a rate of 6%;
Applies to any recreational vehicle or camping shelter intended and used for temporary occupancy for a period not exceeding 30 days; and
Shall be distributed in the same manner as the hotel rental tax under § 9-318(b)(4) of this title.

subsection.text: Subject to the limitation under subsection (a-2)(2) of this section, a county or municipal corporation shall set the tax rate.

A county or municipal corporation may require the operator or owner of a trailer park or mobile home court or park to collect the tax and to remit it to the county or municipal corporation or to the agency that the county or municipal corporation designates.
A county or municipal corporation may provide for:

paragraph.text: The maintenance of suitable public records in connection with the tax and its collection; and
The inspection or publication of the records.

subsection.text: A county or municipal corporation may provide for penalties for the failure to comply with the requirements relating to the tax.
This section does not affect or eliminate any requirement or provision concerning permits to locate a trailer, house trailer, trailer coach or mobile home.
In this section, “mobile home” means a form of housing that:

paragraph.text: Is commonly known as a trailer and house trailer;
Is or can be used for residential purposes; and
Is either permanently attached to the land or is connected to water, gas, electric, or sewage facilities.

subsection.text: Charles County may impose, by ordinance, a tax on the use of a mobile home located in the county.
This section does not apply to a mobile home that is:

paragraph.text: Held on a sales lot for sale;
Unoccupied; or
Located on property used as a mobile home park.

subsection.text: The rate of the tax authorized under subsection (b) of this section may not exceed $250 each year for each mobile home.

paragraph.text: Each person who owns property on which a mobile home subject to the tax under this section is located shall pay the tax to the county office that the Charles County Commissioners designate by ordinance.

subparagraph.text: If the mobile home, the property on which the mobile home is located, or both are rented from the person who owns the property, the property owner shall collect the tax from the occupant of the mobile home.
The property owner may collect the tax from the occupant under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph as a part of the rental fees.
If an occupant fails to pay the tax under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the property owner may exercise any right available to the property owner for nonpayment of rental fees.
A property owner required to collect the tax from an occupant of a mobile home, under subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, may be personally liable for the tax collected or required to be collected.

subsection.text: If the county imposes the tax authorized under subsection (b) of this section, the county also may provide, by ordinance:

paragraph.text: That the tax may be assessed as of the date of finality for the real property taxes of the property owner;
For the maintenance of suitable records in connection with the tax and its collection;
For the pro rata assessment of the tax where occupancy of a mobile home is for less than 12 months per year;
For the penalties for the failure to comply with the provisions of any legislation relating to the tax; and
For other requirements relating to the administration of the tax.

section.text: Garrett County and any code county shall impose, for each fiscal year, a tax on every person exercising the privilege of engaging in or continuing in the business of severing coal by the surface mining method in the county.
The tax rate is 30 cents for each ton of surface mined coal that is reported to the Bureau of Mines under § 15-508 of the Environment Article.

paragraph.text: The county shall exempt from any county tax personal property that is:

subparagraph.text: Used primarily in surface mining related activities, however operated, and whether or not in use; and

sub-subparagraph.text: Owned by a person subject to the tax imposed under § 9-501 of this subtitle; or
Leased by a person subject to the tax imposed under § 9-501 of this subtitle if, under the terms of the lease, the lessor is responsible for the personal property tax.

paragraph.text: Surface mining related activities do not include the activities of any coal washing preparation coal plant.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the exemption of any property from county taxation under this section, the property exempted in any county shall continue to be included in the assessable base of the county for the purposes of any other law, including State aid for education and State aid for police protection.

section.text: The taxes that a county fiscal officer collects under this subtitle shall be deposited in the general fund of the county.

subsection.text: To the extent recorded with the clerk of the circuit court, all unpaid county taxes collected under this subtitle are, until paid, a lien on the personal property and on the real property of the owner of the personal property in the same manner in which a property tax is a lien on the real property with respect to which the tax is imposed in all subdivisions of the State.

The lien will attach to the real property only after notice of the lien has been recorded and indexed among the judgment records in the office of the clerk of the circuit court in the county where the land lies.

paragraph.text: Each year the governing body of a county or the governing body’s designee shall notify officials of municipal corporations and officials of other counties receiving coal tax revenues that the officials may request a meeting with the governing body or designee.

On request, the governing body of a county or the governing body’s designee shall meet and confer annually with officials of municipal corporations and with officials of any other county receiving coal tax revenues.

subsection.text: The governing body of a county may distribute up to 5 cents per ton of the money derived from the tax to the municipal corporations for the reconstruction, repair, or maintenance of municipal coal haul roads and bridges.

section.text: In addition to the powers granted to the county treasurer in this subtitle, the county treasurer may adopt regulations necessary to carry out this subtitle and to define any terms used in it.
A county that imposes the tax under this subtitle may impose interest and penalties for late payment of the tax.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a county may impose a sales or use tax on controlled dangerous substances as defined in § 5-101 of the Criminal Law Article.
A sales or use tax imposed under subsection (a) of this section may not be imposed on sales by any person who complies with Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the Criminal Law Article.
Anne Arundel County may impose, by ordinance, and collect a sales or use tax on:

paragraph.text: Fuels and utilities used by commercial and industrial businesses;
Residential, commercial, and industrial telephone service; and
Space rentals.

Any revenues collected under the authority of subsection (a)(1) and (2) of this section within the boundaries of the City of Annapolis shall be allocated and distributed in equal amounts to the City of Annapolis and to Anne Arundel County.

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, any revenue generated within the boundaries of the City of Annapolis from the tax on space rentals shall be collected and retained by the City of Annapolis.
Any revenue generated within the boundaries of the City of Annapolis from the hotel tax shall be collected by Anne Arundel County.
From any revenue generated within the boundaries of the City of Annapolis from the hotel tax, Anne Arundel County shall distribute:

subparagraph.text: In fiscal year 2012:

sub-subparagraph.text: 2% to the Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc.; and
8% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau;

subparagraph.text: In fiscal year 2013:

sub-subparagraph.text: 2.5% to the Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc.; and
12.5% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau; and

subparagraph.text: In fiscal year 2014 and each fiscal year thereafter:

sub-subparagraph.text: 3% to the Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc.; and
17% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau.

paragraph.text: After making the distributions required under paragraph (4) of this subsection, the balance of the revenue generated within the boundaries of the City of Annapolis from the hotel tax shall be distributed to the City of Annapolis.

subsection.text: Anne Arundel County may not impose a sales and use tax on space rentals for the docking or storage of boats.

paragraph.text: Anne Arundel County, from the county’s share of any revenue from the hotel tax, shall distribute:

subparagraph.text: In fiscal years 2010 and 2011, 7% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau;
In fiscal year 2012:

sub-subparagraph.text: 2% to the Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc.; and
8% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau;

subparagraph.text: In fiscal year 2013:

sub-subparagraph.text: 2.5% to the Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc.; and
12.5% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau; and

subparagraph.text: In fiscal year 2014 and each fiscal year thereafter:

sub-subparagraph.text: 3% to the Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc.; and
17% to the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau.

paragraph.text: After the distributions required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the balance of the county’s share of revenue from a hotel tax shall be credited to the general fund of the county.

subsection.text: The Arts Council of Anne Arundel County, Inc. and the Annapolis and Anne Arundel County Conference and Visitors Bureau shall report to the Anne Arundel County Executive and the members of the General Assembly representing Anne Arundel County on their use of hotel tax revenue during the preceding fiscal year.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the County Council for Prince George’s County may impose, by ordinance, and collect, in a percentage no greater than the percentage in effect on July 1, 1992, a sales or use tax on any form of energy or fuel used in Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: Motor vehicle fuels;
Fuels used in the production of other forms of energy that are subject to this tax; or
Energy or fuel used by a municipal corporation in the county.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, subject to subsection (d) of this section, the sale or use of energy or fuel used by the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission in Prince George’s County is not exempt from the tax imposed under this section.

subsection.text: The County Council shall provide for the refund of the tax imposed under this section to persons who are eligible for a tax credit under § 9-102 or § 9-104 of the Tax - Property Article or for weatherization or energy assistance from the State.
The County Council may:

paragraph.text: Provide exemptions from the tax imposed under this section in addition to the exemptions under subsection (b) of this section; and
Provide for the refund of the tax imposed under this section to persons who are not eligible for a refund under subsection (c) of this section.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the tax imposed under this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: Either a percentage of the net energy or fuel bill or an amount per unit of fuel or energy;
Itemized on the bill; and
Collected by the vendor on behalf of the county.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the tax imposed under this section:

subparagraph.text: May not be considered part of the price charged for the energy or fuel; and
Is not subject to the approval of the Public Service Commission.

paragraph.text: Heating fuel vendors may include the tax imposed under this section as part of the price charged for fuel oil. The fuel oil bill shall state clearly that the local tax is included in the price. The tax shall be collected by the vendor on behalf of the county.

subsection.text: The net proceeds of this tax revenue shall be used only for:

paragraph.text: Funding of public education within the instructional salaries, instructional materials and related costs, special education, and fixed charges budget categories in Prince George’s County; or
Funding of the public ethics provisions under Title 15, Subtitle 8, Part IV of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: For each fiscal year, Prince George’s County shall appropriate local funds to the school operating budget in an amount not less than the sum of:

paragraph.text: The excess of the amount of the projected revenues for the fiscal year from the tax authorized under this section over the projected revenues from the tax for the prior fiscal year; and
The amount of local funds that Prince George’s County is required by State law to appropriate to the school operating budget.

subsection.text: In this section, “Board” means the Board of County Commissioners of St. Mary’s County.
Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Board may impose, by ordinance, and collect a sales or use tax on any form of energy or fuel used or consumed in St. Mary’s County.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: Motor vehicle fuels;
Fuels used in the production of other forms of energy that are subject to this tax; or
Energy or fuel used by a municipal corporation in the county.

paragraph.text: Before the Board imposes the tax under this section, the Board shall hold a public hearing which:

subparagraph.text: Shall be advertised twice by publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county at least 10 days before the hearing; and
May not be part of the annual budget hearing.
If the tax imposed under this section is imposed as a percentage of the net energy or fuel bill, the rate of the tax may not exceed 5%.

If the tax imposed under this section is imposed as an amount per unit of fuel or energy, the amount per unit for each separate classification of energy or fuel, for any fiscal year, may not exceed 5% of the sum of the total amounts billed in the county by all vendors for energy or fuel subject to the tax within that classification during the calendar year that ends before the beginning of the fiscal year divided by the total number of units of energy or fuel subject to the tax within that classification used or consumed in the county during the calendar year that ends before the beginning of the fiscal year.

paragraph.text: The Board may provide for the refund of the tax imposed under this section to persons who are eligible for a tax credit under § 9-102 or § 9-104 of the Tax - Property Article or for weatherization or energy assistance from the State.
The Board may provide for the refund of the tax imposed under this section to additional classes of persons based on age, income, or charitable endeavors.
The Board may establish different rates of tax on energy or fuel used for residential, commercial, and industrial purposes.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, the tax imposed under this section shall be:

subparagraph.text: Either a percentage of the net energy or fuel bill or an amount per unit of fuel or energy;
